page.title: 09 FAUNA AND FLORA OF GREETE
page.content: The area includes a wide range of habitatsfor example,arable fields, woods, rough ground, and streams. It is drained by the Lledwyche brook into which run smaller streams which form a network of wetlands, where interesting species of plants and animals can survive. The landscape is undulating with a variation in height from about 76 metres by the brook, rising to 200 metres on the lower slopes of Titterstone Clee Hill.The underlying soils are of Devonian and Silurian origin with some Carboniferous shales. They are mostly loamy and silty sandstones with some marl, dolorite, and limestone. The fauna and flora are thus many and varied, but mainly restricted to hedgerows, stream sides, and woods, since most of the area is extensively farmed. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE
